Award.AwardTitle: Alternative Polyadenylation as a Major Regulatory Mechanism of Plant Innate Immunity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant disease resistance (R)-genes encode immune receptors that mediate disease resistance upon recognition of pathogenic microorganisms. Their expression has to be coordinated. The investigators previously identified a new process that controls the expression of two R-genes in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The main goals of this project are (1) to examine extent to which this new mechanism is utilized in plants for the regulation of additional R-genes and other defense genes and (2) to gain detailed understanding of this new mechanism. Results from this study are likely to have a broad impact on the fields of plant immunity and gene expression control. This project may also lead to the design of new strategies for enhanced disease protection in crop plants. An important component of the project is major involvement of undergraduate students, mainly from minority groups. The project will be linked to classes on biochemistry and biotechnology taught by the Principal Investigator and the ongoing NSF-REU Plant Cell Biology program within the Center for Plant Cell Biology at UC-Riverside. In addition, the project will provide a strong platform for training of postdoctoral scholars and graduate students and prepare them for careers as senior researchers in academia or industry. The goals of the America COMPETES Act of 2007 that emphasize awareness of the responsible and ethical conduct of research are a top priority of this project.

Alternative polyadenylation is emerging as a major mechanism of eukaryotic gene expression control. The investigators previously found the epigenetic mark H3K9me2 to control differential use of polyadenylation signals of the Arabidopsis R-genes RPP4 and RPP7 and to modulate levels of immunity mediated by their encoded immune receptors. This mechanism is controlled by the epigenetic factor EDM2 and several additional newly identified regulators. The investigators further showed this novel mechanism to be responsive to pathogen recognition and to dynamically adjust RPP4 and RPP7 expression. The central hypothesis of this project is that alternative polyadenylation is a major mechanism controlling inducible plant immune responses. The two specific aims that are to be pursued are:
1) Genome wide profiling of alternative polyadenylation events after defense induction; 2) Identify regulatory factors linking alternative polyadenylation to pathogen perception and defense signaling. Alternative polyadenylation has so far not been recognized as a major mechanism controlling plant immunity. This project will provide a genome-wide overview about defense-associated alternative polyadenylation in plants and uncover molecular details of this type of regulatory process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While wild plant species have a strong immune system that can protect them against microbial diseases, modern elite crops have often lost their ability to efficiently resist infections by microbes. Plant immunity is partially similar to innate immune processes observed in humans. Comprehensive knowledge of the plant immune system is critical for our basic understanding of life processes and can benefit agricultural biotechnology as well as medicine. As in humans, the activation of plant immunity requires the “recognition” of chemical signatures specific for the respective invading microbe. In plants and higher animals, including humans, such “molecular recognition” processes are mediated by NLR-type immune-receptors, proteins that can specifically interact with microbe-specific substances. The activity of genes responsible for the synthesis of NLR proteins is typically controlled in a sophisticated manner. Plants (and other organisms) have to strictly control the amount of immune-receptors present in their cells. If the amount of immune receptors is too low, they are insufficiently protected against diseases; if they are too high, negative effects on development, growth and general fitness are observed. Genes are the instructions for the synthesis of a defined protein encoded in the “chemical language” of DNA. The expression of genes (the utilization of its information for the synthesis of the respective encoded protein) requires first the production of a messenger-RNA (mRNA) copy of its DNA-based information. The resulting mRNA is then “translated” into a protein product by the cellular protein-synthesis machinery. Typically the amount of a given mRNA species correlates with the amount of protein synthesized from it. Arabidopsis, a model plant organism, has been very useful for studying the genetic basis of a wide variety of processes that are relevant for plants and other types of organisms. We are using Arabidopsis to study how plants control the amount of immune-receptors present in their cells.

Intellectual merit: We found that the Arabidopsis proteins EDM2 and EDM3 play a central role in determining the amount of mRNAs encoding numerous different NLR immune-receptors. They coordinate the expression of at least one third of all 165 NLR genes in Arabidopsis. While EDM2 and EDM3 enhance expression of some NLR genes that seem particularly important, they limit expression of many other NLR genes to keep their protein levels under a critical threshold. Exceeding this threshold results in a reduction of plant fitness. We uncovered in previous work how EDM2 enhances mRNA levels encoding the NLR immune-receptor RPP7. A default mechanism termed proximal polyadenylation prevents the synthesis of some RPP7 mRNAs from being completed. This reduces the amount of RPP7 immune-receptors in cells. EDM2 suppresses proximal polyadenylation of RPP7 mRNA and, in doing so, promotes the synthesis of complete mRNAs. As a result cells contain larger amounts of the RPP7 protein. In recent work we found the EDM3 protein to assist EDM2 in this function. While EDM2 interacts with RPP7-DNA, EDM3 interacts with RPP7-mRNA, ensuring the completion of its synthesis. EDM2 and EDM3 “stick together” in a protein complex or aggregate. We further found that the EDM2/EDM3 protein complex can enhance expression of additional NLR genes in a similar manner. An important question is how the ability of the EDM2/EDM3 protein complex to enhance expression of some NLRs, while limiting expression of others, evolved.  Based on our new results EDM2 (and likely EDM3) have a second important role in plant cells. They control the activity of mobile genetic elements (aka transposons). Such “jumping genes” can move in a random fashion in a cell’s DNA and can destroy genes by inserting into them. In rare cases, however, the insertion of a transposon within a gene or next to its DNA can be beneficial. Over the course of evolution such EDM2-controlled jumping genes seem to have repeatedly inserted into NLR genes or the DNA next to them. This way EDM2 (along with EDM3) seem to have gained stepwise control over the expression of a multitude of different NLR genes. While we understand how the EDM2/EDM3 complex enhances expression of some NLR genes, it is unclear at this point, how it limits expression of other members of this gene category. We will address this in future research. We also plan to examine to what extent our findings in Arabidopsis apply to non-model plant species including agriculturally significant crops.

Broader impacts: This project provided comprehensive training to one post-doctoral scientist, two graduate students and five undergraduate students. Three of the five undergraduates were members of minority groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines (one African American and two Hispanics), four undergraduates were women and three participated in the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates program. Results from this study are likely to have a beneficial impact on the development of new crop disease protection strategies by breeding disease resistant elite cultivars without negatively impacting their fitness and yield.
